passages.text: August 29, 2025 02:03 AM GMT
Astera Labs Inc (ALAB.O) Price Target

The rack scale AI business has brought with it a \(\) 17\$ billion greenfield opportunity virtually overnight, creating opportunity for, AVGO, MRVL, ALAB, and others. This report gives an overview of the opportunity.

What is scale- up networking? The scale- up network refers to high- speed communication between GPUs/accelerators in the same server or rack. Interconnecting accelerators allows them to function as one large supercomputer, accessing the same memory and processing the same workload. This is distinct from scale- out networking, which involves connecting multiple systems across a broader data center infrastructure.

As compute scales from single chips to full racks, connectivity becomes vital to system efficiency and performance. For the Hopper generation, cloud customers deployed multiple racks of servers which included 8 graphics processors (GPUs) each. Within those servers, each GPU could talk to the other, but communicating from server to server required a scale out connection. For Blackwell's NVL72, NVIDIA started implementing fully connected racks, wherein each of the 72 GPUs has a direct line of communication with the other 71, which is very complex to implement but which essentially treats the entire rack as a single virtual GPU, without the server to server connectivity bottleneck in between. That has changed the game, as now every NVIDIA merchant and ASIC competitor has a scale up architecture coming.
North America Industry View

Morgan Stanley does and seeks to do business with companies covered in Morgan Stanley Research. Source: Morgan Stanley Research

Why did that happen? As Al models grow in complexity and scale, the demand for high- performance computing infrastructure has surged. The scale- up network is critical because it allows accelerators to operate as a single system, eliminating communication bottlenecks and enabling the scale, speed, and efficiency required to train today's frontier Al models. There are multiple scale- up networking protocols used today, and while it's too early to call a clear winner, we see a large enough TAM for multiple beneficiaries, especially in the early stages of the ramp.

We estimate that the total scale- up network was \(\) 4bn\(in 2024 and is expected to grow at a\) 34\% \(CAGR to\) \ \(17bn\) by 2029. The vast majority of the scale- up market today is NVIDIA's proprietary NVLink, which is exclusively used to interconnect their GPUs. We expect that NVIDIA GPUs (and NVLink) will continue to be the majority of the market. However, outside of the NVIDIA ecosystem there is a massive greenfield opportunity with multiple competing technologies, including UALink and Scale- up Ethernet (SUE). By 2029, we see a meaningful opportunity for other connectivity players - including ALAB, AVGO and MRVL- to participate in this market.
Exhibit 2: Scale-up TAM estimate (5mn)
Source: Morgan Stanley Research, Gartner, DellOro Note: Excludes NICs, Plugables/Optics, and Cables

Stock Views: Astera (ALAB), Broadcom (AVGO), and Marvel (MRVL) are all positioning to capture the rapidly expanding scale- up networking opportunity, though each is approaching it differently. Astera's near- term driver is Scorpio- X PCIe- based switch, expected to ramp with the head customer Amazon in 2026, contributing \(18\%\) of 2026 revenue in our base case, with longer- term growth tied to UALink adoption post- 2027. Broadcom is leveraging its Ethernet dominance, advocating for scale- up Ethernet as the hyperscalers' preferred path, with Tomahawk 6 supporting both scale- out and scale- up deployments, and optics/CPO adoption a possibility in 2028 and beyond; we model AI networking revenue reaching over \(\) 9bn\(by 2026. Marvell's main networking exposure is on optics for scale- out, but longer- term, they are also planning to be involved in the UALink switch market and next gen optics like LPO/CPO for scale- up. We think the TAM is large enough to support multiple suppliers, and all the networking players should be a beneficiary of this growing greenfield opportunity.
Exhibit 3: xPU and Scale-up Network Map
Source: Morgan Stanley Research

opportunity. The most prominent scale- up solutions are NVLink (and NVLink Fusion), customized networks, PCIe, Scale- up Ethernet (SUE), and UALink. See Appendix: Key Scale- Up Technologies and Suppliers for more details.

- NVIDIA GPUs: NVIDIA clusters its GPUs using its proprietary NVLink networking protocol. In the NVL72 rack configuration featuring GB200/300, NVLink is extended beyond GPU-to-GPU connections to also connect the Blackwell GPU with the Grace CPU. Looking ahead, we expect NVIDIA to continue scaling-up its GPUs exclusively through NVLink.

- AMD GPUs: AMD scales its MI300 GPUs using its proprietary Infinity Fabric, which enables up to 8 GPUs to be connected within a single server. For the upcoming MI400, AMD plans to deploy a 72-GPU rack configuration called Helios, which will use UALink over Ethernet for scale-up. It's important to note that this implementation is not pure UALink—it's a modified version where UALink is tunneled over Ethernet and relies on Broadcom's Tomahawk switches. That being said, AMD continues to strongly support the UAL standard, which uses IP from their Infinity Fabric. We expect that AMD will transition to full UALink once UALink native switches become available. If there are disruptions in the UAL timeline, we expect AMD to either continue using Ethernet or attempt to develop UALink switches independently.

- Google TPU: Google's TPUs are connected using two key technologies: Inter-Chip Interconnect (IC) for scaling within a rack (intra-rack), and Optical Circuit Switching (OCS) for scaling across racks (inter-rack), forming what's known as a TPU pod. While Google hasn't disclosed a standard number of TPUs per rack, a fully scaled-out pod using the latest TPUv7 architecture can support up to 9,216 TPUs. The number of TPUs in a rack or pod can vary depending on the specific architecture and use case. Large pods are built by directly linking TPUs via ICI into 3D torus structures—such as a 64-chip cube arranged in a 4×4×4 configuration—which are then interconnected with other cubes using OCS links.

- Amazon Trainium: Amazon's Trainium custom silicon uses a proprietary interconnect called NeuronLink for scale-up communication. NeuronLink can connect up to 64 Trainium 2 chips across four Trainium2 instances. We believe Amazon is working closely with Astera Labs to develop a dedicated scale-up switch for Trainium (Scorpio X), which is expected to launch in 2026. Given Amazon's close relationship with Astera and its active participation in the UALink Consortium, it is possible that Amazon's ASICs will eventually transition to UALink once compatible switching hardware becomes available.

What do we expect next gen xPUs to use? We expect multiple new accelerators to come to market in the coming years. Beyond proprietary fabrics, two technologies are emerging as key contenders: UALink and Scale- Up Ethernet (SUE). UALink is a memory- semantic interconnect purpose- built for AI, though it is still in early stages of development (it was recently ratified earlier this year and there are no UAL products available today). UAL is backed by a consortium that includes AMD, ALAB, MRVL, and multiple hyperscalers. The UAL technology is based off of AMD's Infinity Fabric, and leverages Ethernet for the physical layer and UAL for the protocol/transport layer. We expect Astera Labs and Marvell to be the main suppliers for the UAL networking ecosystem. Meanwhile,

Broadcom's SUE uses an AI optimized Ethernet that has ultra- low latency and high performance built for scale- up. SUE uses Broadcom's Tomahawk switches; the 6th generation built for both scale- out and scale- up shipped in June. NVIDIA also recently introduced NVLink Fusion, which extends NVLink to support hybrid configurations involving custom ASICs or CPUs, though we view this mostly as an extension of NVLink into the scale- out market where non- NVIDIA CPUs are used.

We eventually expect non- NVIDIA XPUs to gradually coverage around an open ecosystem standard like UALink or Ethernet, though we are in the early innings of this market - we don't expect to see a UALink native switch to ramp in volume until 2027. Given how nascent the market is, it's difficult to compare the two standards, but in our view the market is large enough to support multiple suppliers. However, any delays or disruptions in the UALink roadmap would allow SUE/Broadcom to capture most of the non- NVIDIA scale- up opportunity, in our view.
Exhibit 6: xPU and Scale-up Network Map
Source: Morgan Stanley Research

Copper vs. optics? Today's scale- up interconnects are predominantly copper- based, driven by a combination of physical limitations, cost efficiency, and system design tradeoffs. Scale- up distances are typically short—less than 1–2 meters—covering chip- to- chip, board- to- board, backplane, or direct attach cable (DAC) connections. At these ranges, copper excels in both performance and affordability, avoiding the additional cost and power overhead associated with optical components like transceivers, photonics, and laser drivers. Copper links also offer nanosecond- level latency, as they bypass the delays introduced by serialization/deserialization and optical- to- electrical conversion, making them the optimal choice for tightly coupled accelerator systems.

In practice, the maximum number of accelerators in a single rack we see deployed today is 72 - NVIDIA's NVL72 rack. Other accelerator racks are generally in the 64- 72 range today. As we move beyond \(100+\) PUs in one rack, optical connections may be necessary. The key limitations to the number of accelerators you can scale- up in on rack are:

- Fabric limits: Every scale-up switch has a limited number of connection points and bandwidth, which determines how many GPUs can be linked together efficiently. Eventually, you hit a limit where no more connections can be added. Also, as the

system grows, the network becomes more spread out, which means data has to travel through more steps—adding delays and reducing overall performance- Power & Cooling: Extending the distance for high-speed signals can weaken their quality, which means extra components—like equalizers or optical systems—are needed to keep the signal strong. These additions significantly increase power usage. For example, a rack with 72 GPUs can consume over 100 kilowatts, pushing the limits of what even the most advanced liquid cooling systems can handle.- Physical Density: As systems scale to hundreds of accelerators, physical density becomes a major challenge. The bulk and weight of cables can overwhelm racks, while tightly packed setups risk signal degradation and thermal issues, making reliable performance harder to maintain.- Reliability: Larger setups increase the risk of failures—from cables to switches—and even small issues can disrupt performance across the entire system.

We expect copper to be used for scale- up networking as long as possible given its performance and cost profile. However, we could see the introduction of optics as scale- up goes beyond a single rack to cluster hundred of GPUs, though we don't expect to see this until at least 2028. SUE, PCIe, UAL, and NVLink could all eventually operate over optical links. See (Next- Gen Optical Technologies: OCS, CPO and LPO, Oh My and New Page for Networking Market; Initiate FOCI at OW for more on developing optical innovations)

MS View: NVIDIA should maintain the vast majority of the scale- up TAM nearterm, while AVGO, ALAB, and MRVL stand to benefit from the ramp of alternative XPUs. We expect the scale- up market to grow at a \(34\%\) CAGR from 2024- 2030 to \(\) 17bn. The scale- up market is large enough to support multiple technologies, but opportunity is too nascent to declare winners at this point.

We estimate the scale- up market in 2024 was \(\sim\) \(4bn\) , with the vast majority of that being NVLink (Exhibit 7; Exhibit 3). In the April quarter, NVIDIA quantified NVLink shipments exceeding \(\) 1bn\(in the quarter. This was the first time NVIDIA provided a specific dollar amount for NVLink, and they commented that the increase was largely due to the availability of GB200. As we move to rack scaling and beyond, the scale- up network becomes critical to infrastructure and enabling AI workloads. We expect the market for the scale- up fabric to slightly outgrow the XPU market from 2024- 2030, growing at a\) 34\% \(CAGR to\) \ \(17bn\) as accelerator architecture shifts toward system- level optimization.
Exhibit 7: Scale-up TAM estimate ( \(\) mn\$
Source: Morgan Stanley Research, Dell'Oro, Gartner Note: Excludes NICs, Optics, and Cables
Exhibit 8: We expect scale-out spend as a % of XPU spend to increase from \(3\%\) to \(5\%\) by 2029
Source: Morgan Stanley Research

As we see more NVIDIA alternatives ramp this year and next, we expect to see broader deployment of scale- up fabrics. ALAB expects scale- up connectivity to add an incremental \(\) 5bn\(TAM for them by 2030 and a representative from Arista commented that they could eventually see scale - up market to be as big as the scale - out network. In 2028 and beyond, we could also see the introduction of optics in the scale - up network. We still expect NVIDIA to have the majority of the share from NVLink.

Who would win? NVIDIA should maintain vast majority of TAM near- term, while AVGO, ALAB, and MRVL stand to benefit from the ramp of alternative XPUs. At this point, the market is too nascent to determine which scale- up technologies will ultimately win as architectures, standards, and customer preferences remain in flux, but we think the market is large enough to support multiple suppliers. We believe the key factors that will determine the eventual winners are: the division of XPU market share among Nvidia, AMD, and ASIC accelerators; the evolution of new networking standards like UAL and SUE; and the data center architecture choices made by customers. We expect that NVLink will continue to be the majority of the market near- term, reflective of NVIDIA's share. Outside of NVIDIA, we expect the eventual migration from proprietary scale- up networks to open sourced solutions like UAL and SUE. These technologies will be more prevalent in the 2027/2028 time frame as technologies develop and new ASICs ramp.

ALAB: Scorpio- X driving near- term opportunity, long term growth from UALink. As recently discussed during their latest earnings call, Astera sees a significantly expanded scale- up market opportunity, driven by the evolution from PCIe- based systems to UALink technology. While PCIe remains relevant in the near to medium term, especially among the current \(10+\) customers, their long- term vision centers on UALink becoming the standard for AI networking, which should expand their opportunity even more. We expect their Scorpio X scale- up switch for PCIe- adjacent and custom fabrics to enter volume production in 2026 with their lead customer, Amazon. In the future we expect them to announce UALink switches/products, but we don't expect to see significant volume until 2027 at the earliest.

How big can ALAB's scale- up opportunity be near- term? We expect the Scorpio switch to be \(10\%\) of revenue this year, aligned with company commentary. Most of the revenue this year is from their Scorpio P switch, which is for scale- up. We expect meaningful growth for scale- up in 2026, as Scorpio- X ramps in volume. There is some optionality in the size of this opportunity - it is levered to Amazon Trainium, which we continue to hear is significantly lower performance than merchant GPUs, but Amazon is clearly committed to the project. In our base case, we assume that Scorpio revenue will grow to \(\) 186\mathrm{mn}\(more than doubling y/y and contributing to\) 18\% \(of total revenue in 2026. This includes both P series and X switches, but we expect\) 70\% \((\sim\) 130mn) to be Scorpio- X. The size of ALAB's scale- up opportunity in 2026 depends on the number of Trainium units that are deployed in racks with the Scorpio- X switch, but for our base case we assume 650k Trainium units scaled- up with Scorpio, with an attack rate of \(25\%\) and an ASP of \(\) 800\(. However, we do see significant upside depending on what architectural decisions Amazon makes. In addition, the Scorpio- X was described as an anchor socket that brings in other products like retimers and gearboxes, which could drive content even higher. In our bull case, we could see ALAB's scale- up revenue going to\) \ \(400\mathrm{mn}\) in 2026, which would drive total revenue to \(\) 1.5\mathrm{bn}\(. That being said, we generally like to stay more conservative when modeling new networking opportunities given how quick architectural decisions can change and variability in ASIC ramps.

Thoughts on the stock: Astera offers the best growth rates in our coverage, with multiple product cycles and a very strong position in key AI technology - with visibility into multiple product cycles that have yet to even start to ramp. We still expect strong potential for upside to ALAB numbers for the next few quarters, especially as they have more content on ASICs, which will be ramping over CY26. We remain OW and are raising our price target, assuming EV to sales to growth ratio above peers at 1.08. This brings our PT to \(\) 200\(on CY26 revenue of\) \ \(1.04\) 0bn. We think a premium is warranted due to Astera's unique AI concentration, which is significantly above peers. In addition, Astera's revenue ramp with new products in scale- out is just starting, and we expect them to be one of the fastest growers in our coverage.

Broadcom sees a huge opportunity for scale- out networking, and recently mentioned 5 to 10 times higher switch density compared to scale- out networking. Broadcom strongly advocates for SUE and sees scale- up rapidly converting to Ethernet, and that Ethernet

remains the preferred choice of their hyperscaler customers. Their recently released Tomahawk 6 has both scale- out and scale- up networking support, and there are multiple large scale deployments planned with XPUs using Tomahawk 6 for scale- up. Broadcom is also a proponent of optics/CPO in the scale- up domain. They believe that once we go past \(\sim 100\) accelerators in a rack, the constraints of copper may require a transition to optics. Tomahawk 6, 5, and 4 all have CPO versions.

We are modeling their AI networking to grow to at least \(\) 9bn+\(in CY2026 from\) \ \(4.5bn\) in CY2024. It's difficult to differentiate between scale- out and scale- up ethernet revenue, but we ultimately expect scale- up Ethernet to become a larger portion of networking revenue in 2027. A frequent question we get from investors is if their relationship with hyperscalers as an ASIC supplier influences the scale- up networking decision. We think hyperscalers ultimately have the final decision, but could see some degree of bundling occurring when Broadcom is the ASIC designer. Their lead ASIC customer Google currently uses their own proprietary networking, but their new ASIC customers and future generations of current ASICs may adopt Ethernet.

Thoughts on the stock: Broadcom is our preferred ASIC supplier play and has one of the most compelling bull cases. While there is significant optionality in their long- term outlook, we think their ambitious 2027 SAM is materially possible. In addition, we are encouraged by the Ethernet share gains in the scale- out market and we see the potential for a similar dynamic to play out in scale- up. Remain OW.

MRVL: Strong position in optics and an opportunities with UAL. Marvell sees a major scale- up opportunity in networking through new interconnect technologies and its involvement in UALink. At the recent OFC, Marvell highlighted their innovations in CPO and LPO, addressing the limitations of copper connectivity for scale- up. Marvell is also a participant in the UALink consortium, and has UALink IPs in their custom compute platforms. While they have less share on the switching side than Broadcom, we still see a significant TAM expansion opportunity as demand for AI interconnects accelerate. We are most excited about their positioning in optical, where they have the lion's share of opportunity on the transceiver side and prospects in the future LPO/CPO products.

Thoughts on the stock: Marvell is firmly in the AI winners camp, and sentiment has swung aggressively negative compared to a few months ago. We are more excited for their positioning in optical, which brings higher margin and durability vs. their ASIC opportunity. While we are constructive on their networking outlook, we remain EW given our tempered outlook on their ASIC business, but would note that it has significant optionality.

ANET: Arista is positioned well in AI opportunity as Ethernet takes share from InfiniBand and front- end use cases grow; scale- up has potential to be incremental in the longer term. We have been OW ANET given a view that the AI networking opportunity is growing for Ethernet (39%+ 24- 29) and Arista is well positioned to capture a share of that opportunity. Reason being, 1) Ethernet is taking share in the back- end of the network from InfiniBand and 2) front- end is a high growth opportunity as inference cases grow (as we have written about here). This is supported by the momentum on the back- end networks as Blackwell ramps and seeing inference traffic growth lead to front- end upgrades sooner than expected. Two of Arista's major clusters are reaching 100K GPUs and the fourth customer is expected to reach 100k GPUs in 2026 and there are 25-

30 Enterprise or neo- cloud AI customers, with the Company expecting total AI contribution to be greater than \(\) 1.5bn\(for 2025 (see 2Q25 results). Arista's AI opportunity in the near term is largely for scale - out networking vs. scale - up networking that is primarily NVLink today. However, Arista expects scale - up networking to move to more open standards in the next few years and believes scale - up networking for Ethernet becomes an addressable market for Arista by 2028. Reason being, as customers get a choice in GPUs, Arista believes customers will prefer an open, flexible and multi- vendor that scale - up networking for Ethernet provides.

NVIDIA uses their own proprietary protocol called NVLink to scale- up their GPUs. NVLink is purpose build for AI and is a key component of NVIDIA's technology moat. Since NVIDIA has the vast majority of the accelerator market, NVLink is the most widely deployed scale- up network today. NVLink is on the fifth generation, and each Blackwell supports 18 links, each operating at 100 GB/s in both directions, giving a total of 1.8 TB/s of bandwidth per GPU. That's double what the previous generation (NVLink 4.0) offered and well beyond the speed of PCIe Gen 5.

To scale beyond single GPU setups, NVIDIA's NVLink Switch chips make it possible to connect many GPUs together. In a configuration like the GB300 NVLV2, up to 576 GPUs can communicate in a non blocking fabric—each GPU having full speed, all to all connections—and the system achieves over 1 PB/s total bandwidth across the GPUs. The combination of massive bandwidth, ultra- low latency, and memory coherence makes NVLink one of the most optimized scale- up interconnects for AI.
Exhibit 10: NVLink in NVL72 domain
Source: https://developer.nvidia.com/blog/nvidia-contributes-nvidia-gb200-nvl72-designs-to-open-compute-project/
Exhibit 11: NVLink vs. PCIe
Source: https://www.fibermall.com/blog/nvidia-nvlink-and-nvswitch-evolution.htm

NVIDIA also recently announced NVLink Fusion, which extends their NVLink infrastructure to platforms with third party accelerators or CPUs. This allows customers to use NVLink with an ASIC and Grace CPU or a custom CPU with Blackwell. If adopted, it would significantly expand NVLink's reach beyond NVIDIA platforms. Thus far, announced partners on the ASIC side are MediaTek, Marvell, Alchip, Astera Labs, Synopsys, Cadence and on the CPU side are Fujitsu and Qualcomm.

PCle is the industry's universal, high- speed interconnect standard for linking CPUs, GPUs, NICs, storage and other devices on the front- end. While more traditionally found in the scale- out I/O domain, it can also be used for scale- up and is the basis for some custom scale- up networks. PCle's wide adoption/familiarity, modularity, and broader ecosystem make it attractive for a scale- up alternative for non- NVIDIA platforms. However, PCle SERDES speed lags behind the other protocols, including Ethernet. Customizing PCle and incorporating protocols like Compute Express Link (CXL) can add features like memory sharing to help performance, but in general, PCle by itself is not tailored to handle AI workloads. In our view, PCle based fabrics will be used as an intermediary step before the availability of an AI- optimized and open standard solution.

Suppliers/Customers: Astera Labs, Broadcom, and Marvell all have PCle products, mostly for scale- out. Astera Labs is known for their retimers, which extend reach and maintain signal integrity. Broadcom thus far has had the majority of the PCle switch market, but Astera also announced their Scorpio switch product (see Astera Labs Inc: New PCle Switch Announced) for PCle and custom scale- up fabrics. Astera Labs mentioned working with \(10+\) PCle/custom customers for scale- up networking during their most recent earnings call, demonstrating broad interest. However, ALAB eventually expects the non- NVIDIA customers to move to UAL for scale- up once available.
Exhibit 12: ALAB products for PCle scale-up and scale-out

UALink is a developing interconnect standard, designed to be purpose built for AI while avoiding proprietary locked- in solutions like NVLink. The Foundation of UAL is AMD's infinity fabric; AMD open sourced Infinity Fabric to the UAL consortium in the hopes of

building an ecosystem around it. The physical layer of UAL leverages Ethernet, while the protocol/transport layer will be the new UAL standard. Essentially, UALink aims to combine the performance of proprietary scale- up networks with vendor neutral flexibility. There is still a lot of work being done on UAL - it was recently ratified 5 months ago and there are no UAL products available today - but there is a long list of members on the UAL consortium, including ALAB, AMD, Marvell, AWS, Google, Meta, Microsoft, and more.

UALink 200G 1.0 delivers up to 200 gigatransfers per second (GT/s) per lane, with four lanes forming a "station" for up to 800 Gbps of bandwidth in both directions. It uses an Ethernet based physical layer and supports high efficiency features like fixed payloads, virtual channels, link level retransmissions, and encryption. The design also keeps latency very low and supports up to 1,024 accelerators.

UALink focuses on area efficiency (small hardware footprint), low latency, and energy efficiency. It achieves these by optimizing data paths and leveraging Ethernet standards, which reduces both cost and software complexity. It uses direct memory operations to simplify communication and supports scalable infrastructure for growing AI workloads—all while being open and interoperable.

Suppliers/Customers: AMD has been vocal on eventually using UALink, discussing its scalability, performance, compatibility, and open standard capabilities during their recent Advancing AI day. However, UALink switches won't be widely available in time for their Mi40O series. In the meantime, AMD appears to be using a variant of Ethernet with Broadcom Tomahawk switches. On the networking supplier side, ALAB has been a large proponent of UAL, where we eventually expect a UAL switch product. Marvell also announced UALink scale- up offerings.
Exhibit 13: Multi- node & Multi- Plane UAL Switching in a scale- up rack infrastructure
Source: UALink 200G 1.0 Specification White Paper

Scale Up Ethernet (SUE) is a specialized framework developed to enable low latency, high bandwidth interconnects for XPU clusters. It leverages the familiar Ethernet ecosystem, combining high- speed links and switches with a scalable, switch single hop or mesh topology. Each SUE instance supports flexible port configurations—1×800 G,
\(2\times 400G,\) or \(4\times 200G\) - and multiple instances per XPU enable aggregated bandwidth up to 9.6 Tb/s per XPU pair in a fully switched setup.

SUE builds on standard Ethernet but adds specialized features to handle the unique demands of AI workloads. These include link- level retries for fast recovery of lost packets, flow control mechanisms to prevent congestion, and compact AI- specific headers to reduce data overhead. The framework also supports multiple Ethernet speeds (200G, 400G, and 800G) and can scale to clusters with over 1,000 accelerators. To ensure reliability, it provides in- order delivery, real- time load balancing, and efficient error correction, while also supporting command channels that reduce communication delays.

One of the main strengths of SUE is that it builds on widely used, open Ethernet technology—making it easier for the broader ecosystem (switch vendors, accelerator makers, data center operators) to adopt and integrate.

Suppliers/customers: SUE is primarily driven by Broadcom, who is repurposing its Ethernet switch silicon (Tomahawk and Jericho families) for the scale- up domain. Broadcom provides the switch ASICs and the SerDeS technology. While Broadcom is the anchor chip supplier, other networking vendors like Arista and Cisco believe scale- up networking for Ethernet could become an addressable opportunity for them in the coming years.

Cloud Capex Proving More Durable, with AI Opportunity on the Horizon

With upgrade cycles coming to an end, AI investment becomes the driver of cloud investment Enterprise / campus market share gains continue as business is now scaled and provides a more durable growth engine through hyperscale cycle drivers. Initial share gains were possible without significant investment in channel, but greater scale could lead to more reliance to maintain growth, with cost. However, macro/tariffs pressure spend environment. Data center exposure is relatively more attractive within enterprise budget scenarios, affording premium to networking peers outside of cloud upgrade cycle drivers. Opportunity at Google has potential as a catalyst but remains further out.
